moves.3... Nf6 4. Nc3 Be7 5. d4 Nbd7 6. Be3 O-: Up to now, fairly standard hanham formation. 0-0-0 is risky given black's counterplay on the queenside.
moves.11. dxe5 dxe5 12. Ng3: White prepares a kingside attack, while black hopes his queenside attack will prevail first.
moves.12... Bb7: Here black decides an open position with pawn exchanges gives better chances if white takes the pawn.
moves.13. Bxb5: Perhaps better would have been 13 nf5.
moves.19. Nd2 Bb7: The exchanges have left black with strong bishops but the position is basically even, if unbalanced
moves.20. f4: White tries to exploit the position of the black bishop
moves.20... Bh4: this is an essential intermediate move
moves.23. Qh2: White declines the queen exchange, overestimating kingside chances. Now white's position deteriorates.
moves.23... Re8: Now black controls the e-file, and threatens checkmate via a queen sac at e1.
moves.25. Qg1 Bg2: a strong move, driving away the rook while threatening the h pawn.
moves.26. Rd1 Bxh3 27. Qxc5: White wants to keep the material even, but does not see the danger to his king.
moves.27... Qxg4: Black could have played 27...QxR  here, since QxR is met by Re1 .
moves.31. Ne4 Be7 32. Nf2: hoping for a miracle, but the white king is too weak.
moves.32... Qe1 33. Nd3: the bishop was immune because 33 Qxc3  wins
moves.33... Qxc3+ 34. Kb1 Bf5: fishing for a mate,  if white takes the bishop, Black plays 35 ...Qc2 , 36 Ka1, Bf6 ,, #7 Be5, BXB , 38 QxB, QxN.
